What's new? UK Nielsen data 4wks to 6 October. FEVR -2.8% after previous 4 weeks +0.1% (August -8%, July -12.7%, June -3.5% and May -5.9%) vs similar comps Oct-18 +37.3% after Sept-18 +37.7%. Two-year stack at +34.5%, after Sept +37.8%. Overall soft drinks category +3.4% (+5.5% in August) with Schweppes +10.9%. YTD UK growth now at +0.6% after 1H19 co reported growth +4.5%. For F19 we model UK +7% vs street now at 7.5% (down from 9%).

11:16 am
BE11:17am

What it means for our investment case. Having been the key driver of the upgrade cycle over the past few years (F18 +53%, F17 +96%), UK momentum has moderated. 2H run-rate to date at -5.4% implies the UK needs to grow at an average of +24.7% for the remainder of the year to hit street estimates (F19 +7.5%) which looks high to us. We would acknowledge that on-trade could be running faster than off-trade and that a good Christmas could provide a boost, given co-promotions over the festive period. However, if street numbers are shaved for the UK for both current and outer years (top and bottom line), this would act as a restraint on multiple expansion in our view. Given risk to earnings, we stay on the sidelines

Irish HF guy @BE, is it possible to have a fastFT for ML? At least you can push volume thru that channel and we can comment real time, albeit not scrolling real time like ML

UK competitive dynamics. Total UK soft drinks +3.4% (previous 4 wks +5.5%). Schweppes value +10.9% after Sept +14.2%. On pricing, August saw FEVR continued negative price/mix -8.3% after September -2.3%, Schweppes volume +11% (price/mix -0.1%).
Gin category slowing. With 1H reporting last week, Aim-listed Distil (not covered) flagged trading challenges "particularly UK unflavoured gin market where we had fewer promos and retail distribution declined by c100 outlets". Co sees "further softening of the unflavoured gin category into the foreseeable future". Per latest market data, the gin market saw a slowdown during the summer of traditional, unflavoured gin, overall category vol sales down in the 12 weeks to mid-Aug 2019.

BE11:19am

Europe - different levels of maturity. Nielsen data for Europe ex UK, implied growth in 2018 was +18% vs company reported growth of +24%. Per Nielsen, Europe ex UK 4 wks to 6 October +11.4% (prev 4 weeks +16.8%, August -2.9%, July +20.5%) with YTD running at +10.1%.
Good US Nielsen but not enough to offset weak UK. Nielsen US 4 wks to 5-Oct +31.8% vs prior month +32.7%, and +34.9% before this. This implies 2H running at +32% per Nielsen (vs Jeff +29%). Whilst Nielsen only accounts for c30% of Fever Tree US sales, directionally it points to an acceleration. Per sensitivity analysis, if UK F19 slows from +7% (street +9%) to +2.5%, US needs to accelerate to +45-50% for group growth (F19 +14.9%) to be unchanged. With +24% in 1H, US needs to grow c70% in 2H (vs current run-rate +32%) for group growth to remain unchanged.

BE11:30am

With 19 states legalized, 14 live, 11 reporting monthly data, and a good mix with & without mobile betting, we have a clearer picture of what US sports betting will look like, and who the beneficiaries should be. We raise our mkt forecasts and adjust our PTs, highlight PENN and WMH as favored names. We have restructured our US sports betting model, taking a view on online vs. onground, and now forecast a $7B market in 2025 vs. our $5B market forecast made in June 2018 and reiterated in December. While the pace of legalization has actually been slightly slower than we expected, market revenue has been higher, driven by stronger per capita spending, especially in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. We believe we were missing 2 things in our earlier forecasts: 1) that while US bettors likely won't spend the same as in the UK or Australia, a significant portion of the betting in those countries is on horse racing, that will be re-distributed to sports here in the US; and 2) online sports betting is still a growing industry globally, putting upward pressure on eventual US spending. We expect online sports betting to reach $5B of revenue in 2025, and onground to reach $1.5B. For the first time, we are forecasting online vs. onground revenue separately. Onground revenue is driven by proximity to population masses, and popularity of the physical destination, so we forecast based on penetration of existing casino revenue. In contrast, we forecast online revenue based on spend per adult, which we see as properly capturing the broader market opportunity. Our 2025 online forecasts $52 annual online sports betting spend adult, supported by New Jersey's Sept annualized rate of ~$40, and Australia UK's $45 $43 (for context, $81 $57 with horse racing). We forecast onground revenue at 2% of existing casino revenue, similar to what 5 states are averaging today. Together this implies $35 annual sports betting revenue per adult in the 36 US states that we expect to legalize. Lower margin expectations. We now forecast industry EBITDA margins to mature at 25% vs. 30% before. We had forecasted state gaming tax rates to settle out at 15% and while a weighted average of the states that are legal today would imply 15.1%, we expect to see upward pressure. Pennsylvania has the highest tax rate (excluding states run by the lottery) at 36%, which many including ourselves expected to significantly constrain market size. However, the market has been a relative success, so we expect future state legislators to push for higher tax rates. In addition, the cost of marketing / promotional spending as well as media and league partnerships have been higher than we expected. These two factors more than offset expected lower Federal excise taxes because of higher gross win margins, and lower G&A as a % of revenue given a larger market size. Stock implications. With 16 months of data, as well as more recent app download data, we've taken a more definitive view on market share than our prior assumption of giving each of our companies 10%. In the markets we expect they will access, we forecast the legacy DFS players, FanDuel (FLTR) and DraftKings, to reach 15-20% share, FOX Bet, William Hill and Bet365 to reach 10% share, and Roar (MGM/GVC), theScore, and PointsBet 5.0-7.5% share.

Despite concerns over the impact of continuing political uncertainty on housing market activity and consumer sentiment (as highlighted by yesterday’s GFK data), Rightmove’s share price has appreciated by 12% since 4 October when we flagged our growing discomfort around its stock valuation. Based on our forecasts Rightmove is now trading on FY19F PE and DY ratios of 30.3x and 1.2%, respectively.

These metrics compare to equivalent average figures of 17.4x and 3.2% for our watchlist of 27 other UK listed Media companies and, in our view, cast a spotlight on several areas of downside risk.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian In response to Irish, I haven't been on ML everyday and this week other work has resulted in me not paying 100% attention. Sorry. That does not mean I don't value ML.
YourGrannyOnBongos @Super SWF - ML isn't losing enough money to tempt them
BE11:37am

Firstly, we have argued for some time that following a long period of sustained and substantial price inflation (RMV’s monthly ARPA rose by 9% YoY to £1,077 during H1 FY19F versus £308 in FY09A), agents are likely to prove increasingly resistant to paying more - particularly in view of the highly competitive nature of the residential property market. With this in mind, we note that OnTheMarket (OTMP, House Stock at 74p) recently highlighted challenging conditions facing agents including: lower transaction volumes; reduced letting fee income and; a reticence amongst buyers and sellers. It also seems likely that the increasingly apparent impact of Brexit uncertainty on consumer behaviour could feed through to a more cautious approach towards marketing spend. We also note this week’s profit warning from Crest Nicholson^ (CRST, Hold at 388p) which, although partly stock-specific, raised concerns over declining confidence amongst new home buyers – a sector that was pivotal tor RMV during H1 (10% YoY increase in new home developments listed).

Tom Dalgleish ML needs some controversy. To be quoted as a news item ourselves
nightingale20201 @Irish...more about controlling/secrurity vs. opp. cost in London
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Another indication that some advertisers could be reaching a tipping point can be seen in Rightmove’s interim results which saw agent numbers decline by 3% (“mainly low-stock agencies”) with more departures expected by management during H2. We currently forecast YoY declines of 3.0% and 0.5% in agent numbers during FY19F and FY20F, respectively having moderated our expectations at the half year – notably the first time that we can recall reducing our assumptions on underlying agent numbers following a RMV results announcement.

Whilst we would not generally expect agents to entirely de-list from Rightmove for financial reasons, we do think that there is real potential for them to opt for more basic, lower cost listings packages to reduce their overheads and / or divert spend to other lower-cost portals with the intention of increasing their reach and profile and, crucially, improving their ability to secure listings. By way of an example of an alternative option, OTMP has recently signed 2,000 agent offices at an average ARPA of £297 per month.

BE11:47am

Genel this morning published a Q3/19 trading and operating update that includes cash figures slightly ahead of our expectations – cash proceeds of $287m and free cash flow of $121m; as a result, the company ended the quarter with net cash of $115m.

We see upside to our FY19 numbers; however, Q3/19’s cash inflows benefited from Q2/19’s strong oil price – Brent averaged $68.55/bbl – and the company’s slightly lower burn rate – Genel has worked through 65% of its 2019 budget, and spending is expected to be ‘towards the top end’ of its $150-170m guidance. With Brent having eased in Q3/19 to $62.15/bbl, we expect the pace of cash inflow to ease. Debt remains unchanged at $298m. Net production guidance in 2019 is maintained at ~36,900b/d.

Our view: Financially robust, Genel is well placed to pay its dividend, and today management reaffirmed its commitment to growing the payout. Organic growth potential is focused largely on mid-2020 activities at Sarta and Qara Dagh.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian LK Hyman - I've been in finance for the last two decades. So a little rusty on the software side. That doesn't mean the modern IT 'guru' can pull the wool over my eyes.

BE11:47am

Trading update from Genel this morning shows greater resilience than peer DNO yesterday, despite similar production weakness in the quarter. OpCF/FCF are tracking FY run rates and guidance is maintained. We think Genel's attraction lies in its Sarta project, offering growth potential, and it is one of a handful of stocks we forecast will generate its market cap in FCF in the next three years at $65/bbl oil, underlining its value.

BE11:48am

•
Production lower, FY19 guidance maintained. Q3 production averaged 34.7 kb/d
(1H19 37.4 kb/d). FY19 production guidance reiterated at "close to Q4 2018 levels",
36.9 kb/d, FCF guided to the top end of prior $150-170M guidance. Taq Taq produced
10.9 kb/d vs 13.1kb/d in 1H19. 5% lower production at Tawke to 120kb/d gross was
flagged by operator DNO yesterday.
•
Drilling at production hubs continues. The TT-34 well at Taq Taq is currently drilling
and should be completed later in the month, which we think is likely to add another 1.5
kb/d at the field, in line with previous wells. TT-35 will spud in December, targeting the
northern flank of the field. At Tawke, three wells are expected to come online shortly.
• Q3 financials on track. FCF $45M (1H19 $76M), capex $38M (1H19 $72M) and net
cash $115M (1H19 $56M). Capex guidance is maintained "towards the top end of
$150-170M". Commitment to dividend growth is reiterated.

You'd have thought most of this would be in the price, as it was talked about in pubs across the Square Mile for the whole of October pretty much, yet Lookers' warning still has the ability to surprise with its awfulness.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Lookers has issued a Q3 profit warning with material weakness in new car sales and margins the main driver. LFL Q3 new car unit sales fell by 3.2% vs the market down 0.6%. Lookers' new retail LFL unit sales fell by 11.5%. We understand that there were some brand specific supply issues (impacted by emissions regulation changes) as well as weaker demand for certain volume brands. Management also suggests that there was a high level of pre-registration activity in the market, adding to margin pressure (Lookers' pre registrations were down on last year).

Q3 new car gross profit was down c. £7m on last year.

The new car market was clearly tough in September, despite weak comparatives (and we suspect that October has been tougher), but we have already seen Vertu and Pendragon navigate the month relatively unscathed.

On used cars, the performance has been better, with the market stable and Lookers unit sales +2.6% with an improving margin trend, albeit still down on last year. We think gross profit in Q3 was broadly flat on last year.

Aftersales remains resilient, performing in line with expectations and LFL gross profit up 2.9%.

BE11:58am

We understand that Q3 PBT was broadly break even versus c. £12m last year. With new car gross profit down c. £7m and other segments flat/slightly up, there has been continued operating cost pressure, which has compounded the weak trading performance.

We expect this to be an area of immediate focus - we do not think that Lookers has adapted its cost base to the trading environment quickly enough.

As a result of the Q3 performance and, assuming continued tough trading conditions in Q4, management is guiding to FY19E underlying PBT of £20m, versus our previous estimate of £37.8m.

New CFO, Mark Raban, is also making some presentational changes so that share based payments, debt issue costs and net interest on pension scheme obligations will be treated as underlying items. This will have a c. £4m impact, meaning that on the revised basis FY19E PBT is expected to be c. £16m. We present our numbers on this basis.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

CEO Andy Bruce and COO Nigel McMinn are stepping down with immediate effect.

Until permanent successors are appointed, Chairman Phil White will take on an executive role and Richard Walker, currently a non-exec, will assume a part time executive role.

Consolidation of the dealership portfolio is being accelerated, with 15 dealerships to be closed and, where possible, relocated/consolidated into existing dealerships in adjacent territories.

One off closure costs will be c. £8m (£6m cash) with the annualised benefit likely to be c. £3m. With nine of the sites being freehold, and four other sites being sold, property disposal proceeds of c. £28m (in aggregate above book value) are expected, of which half should be delivered in FY19E.

The FCA investigation is ongoing. The one-off investment of £10m and £3m ongoing that Lookers had previously announced to address internal control issues was already in our numbers. The improvement plan should be implemented by the year end.

PBateman imagine the LSE board is loving it up
Blank canvas Thanks for everything today from both sides of the page. Enjoy your weekend BE, soon this nightmare will be over
BE11:59am

We cut FY19E PBT by 57.6% - hard to forecast upside in FY20E

Reflecting management's guidance and incorporating the presentational changes discussed above, we cut our FY19E PBT by 57.6%.

The market is tough and Brexit uncertainty will not help with consumer confidence going into FY20E. However, there are clearly operational issues that need to be addressed at Lookers and this will take some time, along with the need to find a new CEO and COO.

We expect the work on cost control and working capital management to provide some mitigation in FY20E, but it is hard to forecast any material growth in profits at this stage.

Despite the cut to profit forecasts, we do not expect a material worsening in the debt position, given tighter working capital management, as well as property disposal proceeds. On our revised estimates, FY19E net debt/EBITDA is not onerous at 1.3x albeit fixed charge cover at 1.4x is low.

We now assume that no final dividend will be paid for FY19E and cut outer years to zero.

Lookers has underperformed the new car market for the first
time in many years, hit by the effect of new emissions regulations
on supply, slower performance in the volume brands and margin
pressure. The effect is to take c£20m off our previous underlying
PBT forecast of c£39m. Also, previous adjusting items, such as
share-based payments and pension interest costs, totalling £4m
pa will now be taken above the line, taking overall PBT down to
£15.5m for FY19. Used car and Aftersales revenues both
delivered growth. The balance sheet remains strong, with the
acceleration in portfolio consolidation generating consideration
of c£28m. CEO Andy Bruce and COO Nigel McMinn have
stepped down from the Board with immediate effect, with
Chairman Phil White assuming an executive role until
permanent successors have been appointed.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

We had expected new car gross profits to decline
marginally this year, down c£3.5m. However, having fallen by £7m over the stronger
quarter, we now assume a similar performance over Q4. We downgrade our used car
GP forecast by £3.5m for the year. The net effect is c£20m cut in adj PBT to
£19.5m; management has guided to £20m. Also, previous adjusting items of sharebased
payments, debt issue costs and net interest on pension scheme obligations will
be presented as underlying items above the line, taking a further £4m off our PBT
forecast to £15.5m, 3.1p. For 2020, we continue to assume a flat market for new cars
and expect the supply issues Lookers has experienced over H2 to be resolved.
Keeping margins flat yoy, a prudent view, the profit outlook for 2020 remains
relatively flat also at £17.6m, EPS 3.5p. The balance sheet remains strong, with net
debt of c1.3x EBITDA and property values equivalent to c80p per share.
